properties.popupContent: Within the last year, the Huangluo village became very popular in lifestyle blogs. Their tradition of using fermented rice water from their crops resulted in women with hair as long as two meters! Using the rice water with other fragrants, like citrus peels or ginger roots, provides a nutrient rich cocktail to promote healthy hair growth.
properties.title: Rice Water

properties.popupContent: While other locked hairstyles can be found around the world, with early depictions in ancient India, the term dreadlocks as we know it comes from the rastafarian religion developed in the 1930s. The locs represents the wearer’s connection with Jah.
properties.title: Dreadlocks

properties.popupContent: For long and luscious hair, women in Guyana increase their intake of sardines -- one of the best sources of omega-3 fatty acids.
properties.title: Cactus Oil

properties.popupContent: While this practice has certainly spread across the Atlantic ocean and throughout diasporic migrations, the use of avocado as a hair mask to strengthen and rejuvenate hair is traced back to pre-colonial Colombian traditions.
properties.title: Avocado Masks

properties.popupContent: For long and luscious hair, women in Guyana increase their intake of sardines -- one of the best sources of omega-3 fatty acids.
properties.title: Omega-3 Fatty Acids

properties.popupContent: In salons across the country, women take part in the “velaterapia” procedure, where a stylist burns off split ends to seal in hydration.
properties.title: Treating Split Ends

properties.popupContent: Senegalese twists are a popular protective hairstyle technique across the diaspora and originates from Senegal.
properties.title: Senegalese Twists

properties.popupContent: Indigenous peoples from the Amazonas in South America have been documented to use yucca as a natural cleanser and protect themselves from the heat and humidity.
properties.title: Yucca

properties.popupContent: During slavery, native Africans were banned from practicing their hair rituals. The grueling labor and lack of resources made cornrows the easiest way to manage their hair. Slicked with bacon grease, butter, or kerosene, slaves’ cornrows were also used to send messages to runaways looking for directions to a safehouse or store food for those making their way to freedom.
properties.title: Cornrows

properties.popupContent: While the origins of Marley, Passion, and Havana twists are largely disputed, they’re the most popular among Black communities in the United States. Similar to Senegalese twists, these are protective hairstyles created by twisting the hair with specific types of synthetic hair to create the desired look.
properties.title: Marley, Havana, and Passion Twists

properties.popupContent: What we know as bantu knots come specifically from the largest Bantu group in Africa, the Zulu tribe located in South Africa. The knots, formed by wrapping sections of hair around itself, are not only a protective style but represent social status for members of the tribe.
properties.title: Bantu (Zulu) Knots

properties.popupContent: One of the more popular methods that comes from the African continent is the use of shea butter to hydrate, protect, and style natural hair. Shea butter is also used as a topical treatment for dry skin, healing burns, and helping fade stretch marks.
properties.title: Shea Butter

properties.location: West Africa and the Sahel region
properties.popupContent: One of the more recognizable braiding techniques among the African diaspora, the Fula people are known for their intricate braided and beaded hairstyles.
properties.title: Fulani braids

properties.popupContent: The Hamar tribe in southwestern Ethiopia wear thin ochre dreadlocks, called goscha, created by mixing resin with water. To decorate, colorful beads are added. Pre-adolescent women wear thin cornrows decorated with beads
properties.title: The Hamar Tribe

properties.popupContent: Women in the Himba tribe, located in northwestern Namibia, wear dreadlocks with other braided hairstyles to reflect social status. The locs are crafted from a mix of human hair, ground ochre, goat hair, and butter.
properties.title: The Himba tribe
